Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: I have looked into this idea a lot ,  BOINC computations seem a match made in heaven.  The main hurdle of a BOINC crypto is the economic structure , Gridcoin and similar coins have gone the route of rewarding users with a coin,  the issue comes with a lack of utility of the coin.  Other than trading it for BTC / ETH there is nothing you can do with it.  The problem is made harder in that pretty much all BOINC projects are volunteer based .    A coin based on BOINC  needs to have a utility , some reason a person will keep on to and use the coin.  I have found a project out of the university of Brno in CZ that is a BOiNC based hashcat distribution ,  this could be an example of a public utility BOINC project.  People use the coin for work prioritization .  Other BOiNC projects can be rewarded as well but one has to be cognizant of the issues ( some people try and game the system to get more credits and in doing so sabotage the research being done )

Author: hyperDEX#6586
Content: bitcoin electricity use these days is getting greener every year, renewables without a way to transmit or store is the cheapest source of power

Author: hyperDEX#6586
Content: It is a myth that eventually bitcoin mining will have a big impact on climate change, cruise lines do more damage right now

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: I will argue for BOINC from a different perspective ,  that of user acquisition,  BOINC has a big community and many people are willing to contribute to research additionally with the crunch on worthwhile gpu and cpu minable coins this gives them a way to earn and contribute without competition found in mining

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: would the developments going on in #cc-pegs be accurately described as enabling an independent platform offering collateralized loans and stablecoins for many crypto assets?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: thx

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: note that the loans are at 0% and there is no counterparty, it is purely with the blockchain.

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
it is based on the USD price of the collateral?  (i would guess, yes for USDK)

when paying back the stablecoin, there is no fee? (hence the 0%)

in the case that KMD is used as collateral, the rewards would still be accruing?

if so, will the rewards go to the depositer upon release, or would they go to some "fund", or do they just not exist?  or is there automated blockclaim re-deposit to claim the reward monthly?

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
> in the case that KMD is used as collateral, the rewards would still be accruing?
> if so, will the rewards go to the depositer upon release, or would they go to some "fund", or do they just not exist?  or is there automated blockclaim re-deposit to claim the reward monthly?

in the current design, the rewards are for the maintainance costs of the multisig signers' servers

> it is based on the USD price of the collateral?  (i would guess, yes for USDK)
yes
if the stable coin is pegged to BTC and collateral is KMD, KMD/BTC price is used

> when paying back the stablecoin, there is no fee? (hence the 0%)

if the price did not go below a certain amount and the debt ratio was always below 80%, afaik, there is no fee

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you issued X stablecoins, you can pay back X stablecoins to release all collateral
